segment.source: This topic for the IT professional describes how to manage the lockout feature for the Trusted Platform Module (TPM) in Windows.
segment.target: This topic for the IT professional describes how to manage the lockout feature for the Trusted Platform Module (TPM) in Windows.

segment.source: About TPM lockout
segment.target: About TPM lockout

segment.source: The TPM will lock itself to prevent tampering or malicious attacks.
segment.target: The TPM will lock itself to prevent tampering or malicious attacks.

segment.source: TPM lockout often lasts for a variable amount of time or until the computer is turned off.
segment.target: TPM lockout often lasts for a variable amount of time or until the computer is turned off.

segment.source: While the TPM is in lockout mode, it generally returns an error message when it receives commands that require an authorization value.
segment.target: While the TPM is in lockout mode, it generally returns an error message when it receives commands that require an authorization value.

segment.source: One exception is that the TPM always allows the owner at least one attempt to reset the TPM lockout when it is in lockout mode.
segment.target: One exception is that the TPM always allows the owner at least one attempt to reset the TPM lockout when it is in lockout mode.

segment.source: TPM ownership is commonly taken the first time BitLocker Drive Encryption is turned on for the computer.
segment.target: TPM ownership is commonly taken the first time BitLocker Drive Encryption is turned on for the computer.

segment.source: In this case, the TPM owner authorization password is saved with the BitLocker recovery key.
segment.target: In this case, the TPM owner authorization password is saved with the BitLocker recovery key.

segment.source: When the BitLocker recovery key is saved to a file, BitLocker also saves a TPM owner password file (.tpm) with the TPM owner password hash value.
segment.target: When the BitLocker recovery key is saved to a file, BitLocker also saves a TPM owner password file (.tpm) with the TPM owner password hash value.

segment.source: When the BitLocker recovery key is printed, the TPM owner password is printed at the same time.
segment.target: When the BitLocker recovery key is printed, the TPM owner password is printed at the same time.

segment.source: You can also save your TPM owner password hash value to Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) if your organization's Group Policy settings are configured to do so.
segment.target: You can also save your TPM owner password hash value to Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) if your organization's Group Policy settings are configured to do so.

segment.source: In some cases, encryption keys are protected by a TPM by requiring a valid authorization value to access the key.
segment.target: In some cases, encryption keys are protected by a TPM by requiring a valid authorization value to access the key.

segment.source: A common example is configuring BitLocker Drive Encryption to use the TPM plus PIN key protector.
segment.target: A common example is configuring BitLocker Drive Encryption to use the TPM plus PIN key protector.

segment.source: In this scenario, the user must type the correct PIN during the boot process to access the volume encryption key protected by the TPM.
segment.target: In this scenario, the user must type the correct PIN during the boot process to access the volume encryption key protected by the TPM.

segment.source: To prevent malicious users or software from discovering authorization values, TPMs implement protection logic.
segment.target: To prevent malicious users or software from discovering authorization values, TPMs implement protection logic.

segment.source: The protection logic is designed to slow or stop responses from the TPM if it detects that an entity might be trying to guess authorization values.
segment.target: The protection logic is designed to slow or stop responses from the TPM if it detects that an entity might be trying to guess authorization values.

segment.source: The industry standards from the Trusted Computing Group (TCG) specify that TPM manufacturers must implement some form of protection logic in TPM 1.2 and TPM 2.0 chips.
segment.target: The industry standards from the Trusted Computing Group (TCG) specify that TPM manufacturers must implement some form of protection logic in TPM 1.2 and TPM 2.0 chips.

segment.source: TPM manufacturers implement different protection mechanisms and behavior.
segment.target: TPM manufacturers implement different protection mechanisms and behavior.

segment.source: The general guidance is for the TPM chip to take exponentially longer to respond if incorrect authorization values are sent to the TPM.
segment.target: The general guidance is for the TPM chip to take exponentially longer to respond if incorrect authorization values are sent to the TPM.

segment.source: Some TPM chips may not store failed attempts over time.
segment.target: Some TPM chips may not store failed attempts over time.

segment.source: Other TPM chips may store every failed attempt indefinitely.
segment.target: Other TPM chips may store every failed attempt indefinitely.

segment.source: Therefore, some users may experience increasingly longer delays when they mistype an authorization value that is sent to the TPM.
segment.target: Therefore, some users may experience increasingly longer delays when they mistype an authorization value that is sent to the TPM.

segment.source: This can prevent them from using the TPM for a period of time.
segment.target: This can prevent them from using the TPM for a period of time.

segment.source: If your TPM has entered lockout mode or is responding slowly to commands, you can reset the lockout value by using the following procedures.
segment.target: If your TPM has entered lockout mode or is responding slowly to commands, you can reset the lockout value by using the following procedures.

segment.source: Resetting the TPM lockout requires the TPM owner’s authorization.
segment.target: Resetting the TPM lockout requires the TPM owner’s authorization.

segment.source: Reset the TPM lockout by using the TPM MMC
segment.target: Reset the TPM lockout by using the TPM MMC

segment.source: The following procedure explains the steps to reset the TPM lockout by using the TPM MMC.
segment.target: The following procedure explains the steps to reset the TPM lockout by using the TPM MMC.

segment.source: To reset the TPM lockout
segment.target: To reset the TPM lockout

segment.source: Open the TPM MMC (tpm.msc).
segment.target: Open the TPM MMC (tpm.msc).

segment.source: In the Action pane, click Reset TPM Lockout to start the Reset TPM Lockout Wizard.
segment.target: In the Action pane, click Reset TPM Lockout to start the Reset TPM Lockout Wizard.

segment.source: Choose one of the following methods to enter the TPM owner password:
segment.target: Choose one of the following methods to enter the TPM owner password:

segment.source: If you saved your TPM owner password to a .tpm file, click I have the owner password file, and then type the path to the file, or click Browse to navigate to the file location.
segment.target: If you saved your TPM owner password to a .tpm file, click I have the owner password file, and then type the path to the file, or click Browse to navigate to the file location.

segment.source: If you want to manually enter your TPM owner password, click I want to enter the owner password, and then type the password in the text box provided.
segment.target: If you want to manually enter your TPM owner password, click I want to enter the owner password, and then type the password in the text box provided.

segment.source: Note: If you enabled BitLocker and your TPM at the same time, and you printed your BitLocker recovery password when you turned on BitLocker, your TPM owner password may have printed with it.
segment.target: Note: If you enabled BitLocker and your TPM at the same time, and you printed your BitLocker recovery password when you turned on BitLocker, your TPM owner password may have printed with it.

segment.source: Use Group Policy to manage TPM lockout settings
segment.target: Use Group Policy to manage TPM lockout settings

segment.source: The TPM Group Policy settings in the following list are located at:
segment.target: The TPM Group Policy settings in the following list are located at:

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesSystemTrusted Platform Module Services
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesSystemTrusted Platform Module Services

segment.source: Standard User Lockout Duration
segment.target: Standard User Lockout Duration

segment.source: This policy setting allows you to manage the duration in minutes for counting standard user authorization failures for TPM commands that require authorization.
segment.target: This policy setting allows you to manage the duration in minutes for counting standard user authorization failures for TPM commands that require authorization.

segment.source: An authorization failure occurs each time a user sends a command to the TPM and receives an error message that indicates an authorization failure occurred.
segment.target: An authorization failure occurs each time a user sends a command to the TPM and receives an error message that indicates an authorization failure occurred.

segment.source: Authorization failures that are older than the duration you set are ignored.
segment.target: Authorization failures that are older than the duration you set are ignored.

segment.source: If the number of TPM commands with an authorization failure within the lockout duration equals a threshold, the user is prevented from sending commands to the TPM that require authorization.
segment.target: If the number of TPM commands with an authorization failure within the lockout duration equals a threshold, the user is prevented from sending commands to the TPM that require authorization.

segment.source: Standard User Individual Lockout Threshold
segment.target: Standard User Individual Lockout Threshold

segment.source: This policy setting allows you to manage the maximum number of authorization failures for the TPM for each user.
segment.target: This policy setting allows you to manage the maximum number of authorization failures for the TPM for each user.

segment.source: This value is the maximum number of authorization failures that each user can have before the user is not allowed to send commands to the TPM that require authorization.
segment.target: This value is the maximum number of authorization failures that each user can have before the user is not allowed to send commands to the TPM that require authorization.

segment.source: If the number of authorization failures equals the duration that is set for the policy setting, the user is prevented from sending commands to the TPM that require authorization.
segment.target: If the number of authorization failures equals the duration that is set for the policy setting, the user is prevented from sending commands to the TPM that require authorization.

segment.source: Standard User Total Lockout Threshold
segment.target: Standard User Total Lockout Threshold

segment.source: This policy setting allows you to manage the maximum number of authorization failures for the TPM for all standard users.
segment.target: This policy setting allows you to manage the maximum number of authorization failures for the TPM for all standard users.

segment.source: If the total number of authorization failures for all users equals the duration that is set for the policy, all users are prevented from sending commands to the TPM that require authorization.
segment.target: If the total number of authorization failures for all users equals the duration that is set for the policy, all users are prevented from sending commands to the TPM that require authorization.

segment.source: For information about mitigating dictionary attacks that use the lockout settings, see TPM fundamentals.
segment.target: For information about mitigating dictionary attacks that use the lockout settings, see TPM fundamentals.

segment.source: Use the TPM cmdlets
segment.target: Use the TPM cmdlets

segment.source: If you are using Windows PowerShell to manage your computers, you can also manage the TPM by using Windows PowerShell.
segment.target: If you are using Windows PowerShell to manage your computers, you can also manage the TPM by using Windows PowerShell.

segment.source: To install the TPM cmdlets, type the following command:
segment.target: To install the TPM cmdlets, type the following command:

segment.source: dism /online /enable-feature /FeatureName:tpm-psh-cmdlets
segment.target: dism /online /enable-feature /FeatureName:tpm-psh-cmdlets

segment.source: For details about the individual cmdlets, see TPM Cmdlets in Windows PowerShell.
segment.target: For details about the individual cmdlets, see TPM Cmdlets in Windows PowerShell.
